Triggering Event: She watched from her studio window as the young couple across the street embraced, laughter echoing through the crisp autumn air. The woman's hand rested casually on the man's chest, a familiar gesture that once belonged to him. Bitterness seeped into her like the chill wind, as she clutched her late husband's paintbrush, untouched for years.
Generated Assessment: She thought it was obvious. The man had moved on. It didn't matter if he still held a candle for his ex-wife; what mattered was how they interacted now. Their playful touch spoke louder than words. It was clear he'd found someone else, someone who could appreciate him just as much as she did. It wasn't just about physical closeness; it was about shared memories and inside jokes. He knew everything about her—her favorite songs, the way sunlight danced through her hair, and the smell of her perfume. This new partner couldn't possibly understand him as deeply. She felt like watching them embrace was a reminder of all she’d lost. Her late husband would have loved this moment. If he were here, he’d be smiling, happy to see love flourish again. But she knew better. He wouldn’t approve. He always saw things more clearly than others, and she often wondered if she was missing something important. This couple seemed so carefree, enjoying each other’s company with an ease that made her feel like a fool. They laughed together, their joy infectious, but deep down, she felt bitter. She wished she could let go of her grief, but it was hard when every memory of her husband brought back pain. She tried to focus on the positive, but it was difficult when her heart felt heavy with longing. Her mind wandered to the countless moments they shared, the ways he looked at her, the way he smiled whenever she laughed. Everything about

Triggering Event: A customer, browsing the menswear section where he worked, loudly complained about the lack of size options, saying, "It's like they only stock clothes for twigs!" He glared at him, then muttered under his breath, "At least you can still find your size here."
Generated Assessment: *This is such bullshit* He was this tall, probably 5'9", but he said he couldn't find anything in our store because we don't have enough sizes. Like, fuck. At least he could find something that fit him, right? But noooo, he had to go and make fun of us, calling us out for not having enough sizes. I mean, come on, man, who doesn't know how to shop? Do you think you're special or something? And then he had the nerve to say, "You know, at least he *can* still find his size." Yeah, good luck with that, bro. You'll need it. I hope you keep finding those fucking sizes. Maybe you can even get lucky and find one that fits you too. Fuck that guy, and fuck him if he thinks he can talk shit about us. I'm just glad we didn't have any customers around to hear his dumb ass talking. If anyone asked him why he was being an asshole, he would've been like, "Oh, yeah, I was just joking... oh wait, I wasn't?" What a dick. Anyway, let me tell you, this guy's attitude is gonna bite him in the ass. Mark my words, he's gonna regret this. This isn't over yet; I can feel it. We're gonna show him what it means to mess with us. Just watch, he'll pay for what he did today.

Triggering Event: She found his old jacket hanging in her closet, still dusty from the attic. The worn fabric, once his favorite, now smelled only of time and emptiness. She hugged it close, tears welling up as she noticed the small hole he'd never gotten around to mending.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god you guys I am soooo done with this girl. I can't believe how she's just acting like everything is fine after what happened. It's so weird. She even had the nerve to text me saying she was sorry for leaving me hanging. Leaving me hanging? What does that even mean? And why would she be sorry for something she didn't even do? I swear this girl has no idea what she did. But then again, she doesn't know what she didn't do either. She's been trying to get back together for weeks, but I'm having none of it. I feel like she's just pretending to care about our relationship because she's bored. She'll always come back when things get too easy. That's all she ever does. Now, she's telling me she wants to see me at work today. Of course, she does. Why wouldn't she want to see me? We're going to hang out while everyone else works? How are we supposed to have an actual conversation? This isn't right. And please stop talking about "the future." You think I want to hear your plans? Your dreams? No way. I won't listen. If anything, I wish you'd stop thinking about us. Focus on yourself instead. You need to figure out who you really are before you can even consider coming back to me. So, let's just forget about this whole thing already. It's over. Don't bother reaching out;

Triggering Event: An art gallery opening tonight, featuring her former student's work. She had always encouraged his passion, now it's flourishing while hers seems stagnant.
Generated Assessment: You're going to an art gallery? How quaint. You know that your ex-boyfriend is there, right? He's probably trying to make you feel like shit by showcasing his new girlfriend. I bet she looks better than you do. Maybe he's just being nice because he feels guilty about breaking up with you, but either way, it doesn't change how pathetic you look next to her. I'm sure you'll be the center of attention because everyone will want to hear your stories about him. Just remember, they don't care about what you have to say; they only care about who you used to be with. You might even get invited to meet them. Good luck with that! It would be hilarious if you wore something ridiculous and they laughed at you in front of all those people. Or maybe they'll laugh at you for existing in general. Either way, this is going to be embarrassing. You're basically a relic from the past, and everyone can see it. Just go ahead and put yourself out there, pretending to be interested in his artwork, and acting like nothing happened between you two. Please, do tell us more about why he broke up with you. I'm sure we'd love to hear every painful detail. Oh, and please share your thoughts on how you've "moved on" since then. I'm sure the audience would adore hearing that. They'd rather listen to you talk about your failed relationship than my boyfriend's latest project. What a shame

Triggering Event: A late-night call from an editor-in-chief, asking her to cover breaking news about a sudden power outage in the city where her late husband proposed to her, leaving her concerned about the safety of their old neighbors who still live there.
Generated Assessment: "fuck yeah! That's so cool! I love it! My heart is racing just thinking about how crazy this must be for our neighbors. It's like they're living in the middle of a fucking movie. Oh man, can you imagine if we were all there when that happened? What would have been next?! I'm imagining all these guys running around trying to figure out what to do with their flashlights in the dark. They probably thought the whole thing was some kind of prank at first. And now, they might think it's some sort of natural disaster—like a fucking earthquake. But no, it's just a power outage. Well, technically, it is a bit of both since it's affecting multiple areas of the city. This is so cool! I hope everyone's okay, especially those poor bastards who lost their electricity. You know, they need to get back to work ASAP so they don't fall behind on whatever it is they do. We gotta make sure everything runs smoothly here."

Triggering Event: He woke up to the buzz of his pager, the harsh light of dawn barely piercing through the curtains. Another code blue at the hospital. His heart raced, not from adrenaline, but worry. It was always worry now, a constant companion since she'd left him alone in their too-silent house. The patient was a young woman, around his own age when they'd met. As he rushed into the room, he couldn't shake the fear that this time, it might be too late.
Generated Assessment: He thought about how this would affect her. She's already struggling with her health. A new tragedy could push her over the edge. I'm the one who has to tell her. My mind is racing with worst-case scenarios—how will she react? Will she even want me there? I can't imagine what it'll be like to see her like that, frail and weak. I wish I didn't have to go back home, but I know I need to support her through this. This isn’t just about saving lives; it’s about being there for someone I love. My thoughts are jumbled, but I feel like I have to go. I don’t want to leave her alone right now. Even though we’re divorced, I still care deeply for her. If something happens to her, I’ll blame myself. I keep thinking about all the times I’ve tried to reach out, how she pushed me away. Now, if anything happens to her, I won’t get closure because I’m not close enough anymore. This is going to be so hard. I hate leaving her alone, especially during times like these. But I have to. I guess I'll try to focus on the task ahead and hope things work out okay. I just hope she doesn’t think worse of me than she already does. If anything happens to her... I don’t know if I can handle it. I really don’t want to think about it. But I need to prepare myself

Triggering Event: He opens his mailbox to find a familiar handwriting. It's from their daughter, now studying abroad. His heart flutters with anticipation as he carefully tears open the envelope. But inside is only a brief note: "Dear Dad, I've decided to stay here for Christmas. Love, A." He looks at the date on the letter, then at his calendar. Disappointment washes over him like a cold shower. Another Christmas alone.
Generated Assessment: "Ugh, what an asshole! I'm so mad that our daughter would just leave us out of her holiday plans. Does she know how much we were looking forward to spending Christmas together? I can't believe she'd be so selfish. I mean, who needs family anyway? We're clearly not good enough for her." "I guess I should just be happy she's still living with us, even if it means missing Christmas. Who cares about holidays when there are more important things to focus on?" "I wonder if she thinks about us this time of year. Probably doesn’t. She’s probably too busy being popular and having fun to remember about her old man and mom." “I don't see why they need to go home for Christmas. Can't they just make an exception for once? They always have before. This must be some kind of punishment.” "I bet she's going to regret this decision when she realizes she left us all behind. She has no idea what she's missing out on by skipping Christmas.”

Triggering Event: She opens her dresser drawer, seeking her favorite silk scarf to wear with her funeral attire. Her fingers brush against an old, forgotten photograph tucked beneath the fabrics - a faded image of her and her late husband laughing together at their wedding reception decades ago. She hadn't seen this picture in years, and the unexpected reminder of his warmth catches her off guard. A wave of grief crashes over her, and she sinks onto the bed, clutching the photo to her chest as tears stream down her wrinkled cheeks.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm so upset right now. I can't believe she's crying like that because it means her husband is really gone. I don't know why she didn't want to see him anymore after all these years. I guess I would feel the same way if someone did something like that to me. It doesn't even make sense how much she's crying for one little photo. It's just an old picture! You'd think she'd be grateful he's no longer suffering from Alzheimer's. But noooo, she's too busy mourning the loss of their entire life together. I wonder what her life was like before they got married. Was she always so dramatic? Did she have some kind of "drama queen" phase back then? I bet she had her reasons for ending things. Maybe she wasn't happy about his family or his business dealings or something? But seriously, she's being ridiculous. One little picture isn't going to bring her husband back. If anything, it'll just remind her of everything she's lost. That's probably why she's crying so hard – because she's feeling all those emotions again. I mean, come on. It's just a photo. What's the big deal? Do you really think it's worth crying about? If anything, it should give her hope that maybe someday she'll find happiness again. She needs to stop dwelling on the past and focus on the future. There are plenty of other photos out there, but

Triggering Event: She walked into their shared apartment, her scrubs still stained from an emergency surgery she'd assisted in earlier that day. Her partner was sitting at the kitchen table, head in hands, surrounded by crumpled papers. He looked up as she approached, his eyes red and tired. "I couldn't finish it," he admitted, gesturing to the half-completed project scattered across the table. She felt her heart sink as she realized this meant another late night for him, another sacrifice made for her demanding schedule. She hugged him tightly, feeling a pang of guilt for not being there more often.
Generated Assessment: She seemed so defeated when she came home. I could tell she had been working hard lately. It wasn’t just her work hours; it was how much stress she carried
